Le Mousso Review | Bon Appetit

Chef Antonin Mousseau-Rivard turns seasonal ingredients into a mindblowing 12-course tasting menu at Le Mousso.ORDER THE: tasting menu, which changes with the seasons and also accommodates dietary restrictions (just call ahead). We highly recommended the wine pairing, in which sommelier Alexis Demers presents with enthusiasm, skill, and total lack of pretension (he’ll also graciously pour a half pairing if the whole shebang feels like too much). But if you’re not down for the multi-hour time commitment (and $190 CAD per person price tag), you can snag a spot next door at Le Petit Mousso, the more casual sister restaurant.THE VIBE IS: industrial minimalism meets midcentury modern, with some earthy ceramics and a couple of Scandi-inspired touches. You don’t really need to dress up in Montreal, but why not go all the way at Le Mousso?PRACTICAL STUFF: Open Wednesday to Saturday, with seating at 6 p.m. There is only one seating every night, so reservations are required (available via its website).—Claire SaffitzPhoto by Dominique LafondPhoto by Dominique LafondWE ALSO LOVEAgrikolIn the Gay Village, a rum-fueled oasis run by Arcade Fire DamasAll the meze (and fresh pita!) at this standout Syrian spot in OutremontLoïcAll roads (and great pét-nat) lead to this Saint-Henri wine barExplore City GuidesAtlantaAustinBostonCharlestonChicagoCopenhagenLas VegasLondonLos AngelesMexico CityMiamiMontrealNew OrleansNew YorkParisPhiladelphiaPortlandSan FranciscoSeattleTokyoTorontoVancouverWashington, D.C.GET THE MAGAZINEBA LogoBon appetitSUBSCRIBESign up for Updates on the Bon AppétitCity GuidesSign UpWill be used in accordance with our user agreement and privacy policyBA LogoBon appetitSubscription FAQsMastheadNewsletter SignupAccessibility HelpRSS FeedsSite MapCondé Nast StoreCareersBon Appétit Media KitDo Not Sell My Personal InformationCondé NastFood Innovation Group: Bon Appétit and Epicurious© 2022 Condé Nast.
